Summary Christopher Tang is a UCLA Distinguished Professor and the holder of the Edward W. Carter Chair in Business Administration. In addition to his academic activities at UCLA, he serves as President of the Production and Operations Management Society (2013-2104) and as Chairman of the Advisory Board of the Hong Kong Polytechnic University Business School (2012-2015). He has also served as a member of the International Advisory Board of the Hong Kong City Univeristy Business School (2009 - 2012), and as an external reviewer of the Columbia-London Business School-Hong Kong University Executive MBA program (2009) as well as the Chinese Univeristy of Hong Kong Executive MBA program (2009-2012).  
 
His research spans across different areas including: global supply chain management, retail operations, and social business operations. He has co-edited 4 books, co-written 1 book, and published over 100 academic articles in research journals and management articles in Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, and The Guardian. He served on editorial boards for over 15 international journals and research boards for startup companies. 
 
He has advised companies such as Abbott Laboratories, Accenture, Amgen, Andersen Consulting, Bay Networks, Emerson Electric (Hong Kong), Federal Reserve Bank, GKN (United Kingdom), Hewlett Packard Company (world-wide locations), Honda America, Hughes Aircraft Company, Nestlé USA, IBM (world-wide locations), ICL International, Intertek Testing Services (England), Information Technology Institute (Singapore), Johnson and Johnson, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Kurokabe (Japan), Northrop-Grumman, and Orient Overseas Container Limited (Hong Kong). Currently, he serves as a board member of Asia Pacific Health Ventures (California).

Summary Illumina is the world's largest developer of technology for analyzing DNA and RNA. The NextBio Clinical software platform, which was acquired by Illumina in 2014, allows to rapidly analyze these types of genomics data together with clinical patient data.  
 
Our software is currently being used by large national population sequencing consortia and researchers in the pharmaceutical industry as well as academia. It dramatically speeds up translational research discoveries like oncology biomarkers, drug targets, novel candidate genes for genetic disease and analyzing clinical trial data. Summary I am an aspiring young professional passionate about agricultural development and food systems. In particular I'm interested in building resilient food systems, agricultural education, organic agriculture, systems dynamics, and sustainable animal husbandry. I am also passionate about teaching the next generation of leaders who will help create a better and more sustainable future for the globe.  
 
My master's work explored the emerging discipline of resilience and sought to develop a more holistic framework for combating chronic poverty in social-ecological systems. By developing a systems dynamics framework, the work helped inform resilience programming and identified critical components that should be targeted by effective projects & initiatives.  
 
My professional goal is to leverage my knowledge of sustainability and practical training in education to help guide the education reform movement towards a more sustainability-minded, whole student-focused future. I believe in experiential, integrative education that utilizes projects and performance tasks to improve self-awareness, interpersonal skills and student achievement. I look forward to finding a role where I can couple my current skills teaching in the classroom while simultaneously improving my leadership and administrative capabilities. Community Development Research Urban Education Food Policy Education Business Management QuarkXPress Social Entrepreneurship Program Development Nonprofits Curriculum Design Sustainability Program Management Proposal Writing Volunteer Management Project Management Data Analysis Community Outreach See 34+     See less Education Cornell University Master of Professional Studies,  International Development 2012  – 2013 My Master's work explored the emerging discipline of resilience and sought to develop a more holistic framework for combatting chronic poverty in social-ecological systems. In order to do this, I utilized the theory of systems dynamics modeling to help conceptualize and parameterize the issues surrounding resilience. My thesis proposed a systems dynamics framework to help inform resilience programming and identified critical components that should be targeted by effective projects & initiatives. The work also proposed the idea of an “adaptive-capacity bottleneck” as a phenomenon preventing effective policy-making. Using USAID’s "Policy and Program Guidance for Building Resilience to Recurrent Crisis" as a case study, the paper further explored the role of effective policy recommendations in affecting lasting and measurable change in social-ecological systems facing issues of resilience across the globe. American Society of Animal Science Scholar American Society of Animal Science May 2010 The American Society of Animal Science recognizes students who are enrolled in a four-year animal science curriculum, rank in the top 25% of their respective classes and demonstrate leadership by participating in animal science and university activities. Names of the student recipients are published in the Journal of Animal Science. Summary I have had a career in many roles, as an inpatient attending doctor at the VA, an outpatient child and adolescent psychiatrist, a school consultation psychiatrist, an Assistant Professor at UC Davis School of Medicine and now as the Quality Improvement Director and Staff Psychiatrist at Heritage Oaks Hospital. Heritage Oaks Hospital’s mission it to provide collaborative mental health services to restore and improve patients’ mental health and quality of life. We strive for excellence in providing collaborative services with values of compassion, integrity, respect, responsibility and teamwork. I strive to contribute to this mission by providing evidence based collaborative patient care and by continuous quality improvement.  
 
Board Certified and Licensed Psychiatrist in both general psychiatry and child and adolescent psychiatry. Focused on providing evidence based treatment of mental health illnesses including therapy and medications as indicated. Educator involved in teaching Medical students, Psychiatry residents and Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Fellows. Research experience includes Clinical Trials. Areas of specialty and interest include autism spectrum disorders, mood disorders, ADHD and Clinical Research. 
 
Specialties: Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Teaching and Education, Clinical Trials Research 
 
Specialities include assessment and treatment of children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorders, mood disorders, anxiety disorders, selective mutism, obsessive compulsive disorders and attentional/hyperactive disorders. Treatment modalities include therapy including cognitive behavioral therapy and interpersonal therapy and medications as indicated. Experience Senior Research Scientist PCCI July 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) Dallas, Texas Our mission is to help save a life. We do so by deploying predictive and surveillance solutions around the world that make healthcare safer, simpler, and less stressful. My work focuses on leveraging patterns in unstructured data using natural language processing techniques. Research Scientist Stanford University February 2012  –  June 2014  (2 years 5 months) Stanford, California Do proton pump inhibitors pose a risk for major cardiovascular events in the general population? What are the likely outcomes of cilostazol treatment for my patient with peripheral artery disease? Are allergies a risk factor for uveitis in juveniles with idiopathic arthritis? These are some of the kinds of questions we can answer using data from the electronic health records of millions of patients — doctor's notes in particular. Our novel technology has applications in off-label drug use profiling, severe adverse drug event detection, cohort studies, and phenotypic profiling to name a few. Postdoctoral Research Fellow Stanford University February 2010  –  January 2012  (2 years) Stanford, California When we discover new knowledge, where does it go? Ontologies are formal conceptualizations useful for knowledge representation, information integration, and discovery, search and retrieval. At the NCBO, we develop tools and services that enable researchers in biomedicine to use ontologies. Research & Teaching Fellow University of Oregon August 2004  –  January 2010  (5 years 6 months) Eugene, Oregon People often see the world in sometimes seemingly irreconcilably different ways. They have their own conceptualizations or ontologies. My graduate work was to apply automated reasoning towards ontology translation as a means of automatically integrating information across differing views, which includes translation across database schemas as one kind of information exchange. DB2 Kernel Infrastructure Engineer IBM June 2008  –  January 2009  (8 months) Portland, Oregon Behind giants like WalMart and Goldman Sachs are enormous databases powered by IBM's DB2 technology. I was an intern on the team that developed a new shared-disk cluster technology that enabled these types of systems to scale-up even more than competitors. Specifically, I scoped, designed and implemented the self-tuning memory management and automatic configuration components for the new DB2 architecture. In plain English, my job was to make the database system "smart" by having it automatically reconfigure itself for optimal performance. 
 
IBM is huge and working on a globally distributed engineering team of 600+ DB2 developers and 350k+ employees was quite fascinating. Programmer/Analyst Whitman College June 2001  –  August 2004  (3 years 3 months) Walla Walla, Washington Small liberal arts colleges are great places for exploring a variety of interests. That goes double for the staff who have to wear many hats. I got to envision, incentivise, plan, design, and/or implement all sorts of technologies, including: online voting system, administrative web portal, online course evaluations, weather station, digital asset management system, website reorganization, course management system, print tracking, residence life floor plans, foreign language assessment portal, geological stream-flow station. If that didn't keep me busy enough, I also hired, supervised and mentored 30+ student employees. Some of these technologies (and students!) stuck around more than a decade after I left. Software Specialist, Engineer & Analyst Harland Financial Solutions November 1997  –  January 2001  (3 years 3 months) Portland, Oregon When you buy a house, you sign a pile of legal documents. Those documents contain very specific language that must adhere to both federal and state laws. I worked on technology that incorporated the enormous variation in statutes across all 50 states and automatically produced that pile of documents. Because I was a firm believer in high quality output, in addition to engineering carefully tens of thousands of files of intricate business logic, I also liaised between engineering and customer support, redesigned training processes for engineers, and gladly assisted quality assurance teams. Technical Specialist Cabletron Systems January 1996  –  August 1997  (1 year 8 months) Rochester, New Hampshire In the late 1990s Cabletron took on Cisco. As "the computer guy" for the company's main campus, I engaged head-on in my personal mission to eliminate every last virus on Cabletron's infested hillside headquarters. I was really good at my job: “Consistently exceeds expectations” and “110% satisfaction.” I was also tapped for special missions across the country: consulted for sales executives in DC, deployed offices in Erie PA, setup Governor Jeanne Shaheen's offices (NH, 1996), managed the end-user roll-out during $15M SAP deployment. Our department, headed by ex-Marines, was literally called "Special Services" and I was essentially a secret agent ninja. Experience Affiliate Faculty Teachers College, Columbia University July 2010  – Present (5 years 2 months) New York City and New Orleans Team-Teach Leadership Development in Teams and Organizations, and Collaborative Conflict Resolution: Negotiation and Mediation skills. 
 
From the SPA website: "Affectionately known as SPA, the Summer Principals Academy at Teachers College, Columbia University is a transformative graduate program for public school educators interested in becoming public school leaders. SPA integrates practice and skill development with theory and research using case studies, simulations and teamwork. Advocating innovation and risk-taking to promote institutional change, our program introduces new possibilities for student learning, school improvement, social equity and opportunity." 
 
International Center for Cooperation and Conflict Resolution (NYC) 
Co-teach Advanced Practicum in Conflict Resolution, Part II, skills training and practice in organization consulting. Students contract with major NYC non-profits to assess how the group experiences and manages conflict and provides data and recommendations to the senior leaders of each organization. Affiliate Faculty Stevens Institute of Technology June 2005  – Present (10 years 3 months) Hoboken, NJ Teaching 
 
Currently teaching "Leading Creative Collaboration"​ in the EMBA and Technology Management programs. Students explore and practice the imagination, creativity, and group collaboration skills entrepreneurs need to build and sustain innovative organizations. [Happy to share the syllabus and learn from others who are challenging graduate students and companies to work differently.] 
 
Some semesters: "The Human Side of Project Leadership"​ in the Howe School of Technology Management and online courses in "Leading Across projects and Programs" with students in the U.S, and China. Also co-teach a PhD Signature Course that brings together advanced PhD students from across the university to enhance team leadership, cross-discipline collaboration and business innovation skills. 
 
Consulting & Coaching 
 
Design and lead leadership development programs for companies through the Howe School of Technology Management and the School of Systems and Enterprises. Custom programs range from 3 days, three weeks, to two years. Topics include leading without authority, decision making under uncertainty, collaborating to drive innovation, self-awareness and personal growth, leading change, building teams, coaching others, and acquiring business acumen and judgment. Most programs also involve one-on-one coaching opportunities. Example clients: NASA Johnson Space Center, ExxonMobil, Pearson Publishing, U.S. Department of Defense, CentraState Healthcare System. Owner Unbound Edge Inc November 2001  – Present (13 years 10 months) Leadership consulting, coaching, and skills development training with executives, teams and individuals. Specialize in helping people recognize and use their creativity in leading collaborative change. 
 
Often partner with colleagues who have complementary business strategy, tech innovation and specific industry knowledge expertise when designing custom leadership development programs. 
 
Corporate clients include innovation units in the bio-medical, healthcare, education, publishing, services, communications, energy, defense, and aerospace industries. 
 
Non-corporate clients include artists, writers and performers who are seeking to enhance their artistic careers and the meaningfulness of their work. Summary A recent Amherst College graduate with a degree in History, I have spent the past two years teaching English in France through a French-government fellowship, and then as a research fellow at Stanford Law School. I'm very excited to announce that I'll be starting law school this upcoming fall at Yale Law School! In my spare time, I enjoy reading, writing, photography, playing Ultimate Frisbee, and running marathons. Summary I am passionate about solving important chemical problems through the study and engineering of biology. My past, current, and future research aims to improve the workflow of the selection and characterization of aptamers towards the ultimate goal of developing both in vitro and in vivo biosensors enabling high throughput screening and diagnostics.

Summary I am an engineer and researcher, focusing on VLSI, computer architecture and circuit design. My research focuses on emerging non-volatile memory technologies (e.g., memristor, RRAM, STT-MRAM, PCM, CBRAM, 3D Xpoint, CNT) from circuit and computer architectures perspective. Memristor-based applications, including logic design methodologies, memristor models, and memory intensive architectures. I also investigate energy efficient architectures with CMOS technology. Summary ​I am a choreographer, dancer, leader, health advocate, and conceptualist, who is ready to expand the field of dance. I have chosen art/dance education as my career because it is a necessary component of a distinguished civilization. In addition to teaching dance arts, I am an artist who values expanding society’s imagination by bringing out ideas and issues to explore and express through interdisciplinary collaboration. I am committed to building strong artistry by holding onto high expectations for excellence. Lastly, I use my expertise to consult individuals about communication, interpersonal relationships, cultural competency, and innovation strategies.  
 
---- 
 
My work in the non-profit sector has made me a strong leader on: Non-Profit Management, Public Relations & Marketing, Fundraising, Organizational Leadership, Safety and Culture Development, Quality Improvement & Customer Service, Audit Management, Video & Sound Editing, and Conflict Resolution & Intrapersonal Communication. 
 
In the field of dance, I have taught the forms of: Cunningham technique, Aztec Dance, Vogue & Voguing, Hip-Hop, Horton technique, release technique, Ballet, Contact Improvisation, Dance-Theatre, yoga and butoh. 
 
Finally, I have taught coursework on: Western Dance Studies, Northern Native American Ritual and Performance History, Queer Studies, Performance Studies, Ethnic Studies, Ethnocentric Performance Arts & Dance, Critical Pedagogy, & Dance Criticism.​ Summary ​I am a choreographer, dancer, leader, health advocate, and conceptualist, who is ready to expand the field of dance.
